title: 107_s988
content: The Act may be cited as the "International Anti-Corruption Act of 2001" and includes limitations on foreign assistance. The President must submit a certification and report to the appropriate committees by March 1 each year for countries receiving foreign assistance under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. The report evaluates economic progress based on indicators like comprehensive economic reform and elimination of corrupt trade practices. The certification process evaluates countries based on economic indicators to determine if they are conducive, not conducive, or hostile to United States business. Assistance limitations are imposed on countries deemed hostile to US business. The text chunk states that funds under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 cannot be used for countries certified as hostile to US business. The Secretary of the Treasury must also vote against any loans to such countries in multilateral development banks. Countries certified as hostile to US business under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 face limitations until they show significant progress in implementing economic indicators. Countries not conducive to US business are subject to a probationary period. Countries certified as hostile to US business under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 face limitations until they show significant progress in implementing economic indicators. Unless the President certifies progress, funds for assistance will not be available for countries not conducive to US business. Under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961, countries deemed hostile to US business face limitations until they demonstrate economic progress. The Secretary of the Treasury will direct multilateral development banks to vote against providing funds to these countries. Under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961, countries certified as not conducive to US business face restrictions until they show economic progress. The President can exempt countries for national security reasons. Under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961, countries facing restrictions must show economic progress within 6 months unless the President deems it necessary for national security. Exceptions include assistance for urgent humanitarian needs, democratic reform, private sector development, and free market systems. The Secretary of Commerce will provide a toll-free number for reporting on the progress of countries receiving foreign assistance in implementing economic indicators. Information from the toll-free reporting will be included in the required report. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The term "appropriate committees" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The term "multilateral development bank" includes specific international banks.
